metadata.synopsis: A saloonkeeper (Maureen O'Hara) sides with the sheriff (Alex Nicol) for justice after she's framed for rustling.

reviews: Director Lee Sholem has what amounts to a craze for closing a scene with a meaningless shot. It becomes quite fascinating.
Plenty of violent gunplay, fast movement and a sensationally-gowned Miss O'Hara provide the excitement in the Leonard Goldstein production, as set up in the script by Polly James and Herb Meadow.
Mild Western has good characters and an admirable interest in non-violent solutions to conflict.
This is the old, old story or the cattle baron versus the small settlers. But the film is lifted above the average Western by a new twist.
Maureen O'Hara's Technicolor décolletage is a good deal more impressive than the fiat old plot that surrounds her.
While O'Hara and Bishop shine in an otherwise ordinary Western yarn, Nicol is hopelessly miscast as the heroic sheriff.
